00:20:54.570 --> 00:20:59.950
Every single service must
have a service owner.

346
00:20:59.950 --> 00:21:02.720
That is a service owner within IT,

347
00:21:02.720 --> 00:21:06.630
there is an important
differentiation there, okay?

348
00:21:06.630 --> 00:21:12.160
And that service owner takes
accountability for the entire IT service.

349
00:21:13.170 --> 00:21:18.400
As we move through into service operation,
and as we've looked previously at the life

350
00:21:18.400 --> 00:21:25.300
cycle phases within IT, you'll see
that there were 20 odd processes.

351
00:21:25.300 --> 00:21:29.755
Well, that service owner does not take
accountability for all of those processes,

352
00:21:29.755 --> 00:21:33.400
and that service owner takes
accountability for the service.

353
00:21:33.400 --> 00:21:36.220
And that diagram in the bottom
right-hand corner there,

354
00:21:36.220 --> 00:21:42.420
you will see that each process
applies to each service.

355
00:21:42.420 --> 00:21:46.696
So if we looked at Process 1 and we said
that, that was incident management, well,

356
00:21:46.696 --> 00:21:49.545
incident management applies
to every single service.

357
00:21:49.545 --> 00:21:52.526
And problem management applies
to every single service.

358
00:21:52.526 --> 00:21:57.055
And request fulfillment applies
to every single service, but

359
00:21:57.055 --> 00:22:00.483
you will notice that
each service is separate.

360
00:22:00.483 --> 00:22:06.042
And so each service or each silo as it
is there will have a service owner,

361
00:22:06.042 --> 00:22:11.360
and we use that with accountable again,
and we use the word ensure.

362
00:22:11.360 --> 00:22:17.060
They ensure that value is delivered
to the organization, okay?

363
00:22:17.060 --> 00:22:21.392
So they liaise with the process owners,
but they liaise with business relationship

364
00:22:21.392 --> 00:22:26.000
management as they will
liaise with our organization.

365
00:22:26.000 --> 00:22:29.440
And they will be present in
our service review meetings,

366
00:22:29.440 --> 00:22:33.580
which is where we review performance
against those service level targets,

367
00:22:33.580 --> 00:22:38.370
in service level management and
with our customer as well.

368
00:22:38.370 --> 00:22:41.170
So expect the service owner
to be present for that.

369
00:22:41.170 --> 00:22:45.510
Ultimately, the service owner takes
accountability for a service.

370
00:22:47.080 --> 00:22:50.361
So in this particular section here then,
well,

371
00:22:50.361 --> 00:22:55.321
in the last two sections, we've done
a very, very brief overview of some

372
00:22:55.321 --> 00:23:00.139
of the fundamentals that we learned
within our ITIL foundation class.

373
00:23:00.139 --> 00:23:04.801
Now, I do understand that there
is a lot to learn there, so

374
00:23:04.801 --> 00:23:09.181
please feel free to browse
further the ITIL foundation

375
00:23:09.181 --> 00:23:13.300
material that is available
here through ITProTV.

376
00:23:13.300 --> 00:23:16.290
But what I would ask you
to do now is obviously

377
00:23:16.290 --> 00:23:19.750
to move into your service
operation material, and

378
00:23:19.750 --> 00:23:23.600
to take a look at all of our
other service operation modules.

379
00:23:23.600 --> 00:23:27.984
>> All right, Jo, well, thank you again
for helping us out, and reminding us of

380
00:23:27.984 --> 00:23:31.580
those foundational concepts that
we may be a little bit weak on.

381
00:23:31.580 --> 00:23:33.197
But now with this refresher,

382
00:23:33.197 --> 00:23:37.440
it means that we're ready to head
on to our ITIL intermediate show.

383
00:23:37.440 --> 00:23:39.520
Well, great place for us to sign off then.

384
00:23:39.520 --> 00:23:42.480
For ITProTV, I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

385
00:23:42.480 --> 00:23:43.680
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

386
00:23:43.680 --> 00:23:47.223
>> Stay tuned right now for
your ITIL intermediate introduction.

387
00:23:48.924 --> 00:23:54.318
[MUSIC]

388

>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this show, Jo and Cherokee explain the importance of  ensuring  any modifications to the IT environment affecting new, modified or retiring services meet the expectations of the business, customers and users.
episodes.title: Objectives and Principles

episodes.description: In this show, Jo and Cherokee introduce a high-level view of the communications and management activities which support service transition. They discuss effective ways to manage communications, commitment and more.  Tune in to learn the emotional cycle and understand how to motivate.
episodes.title: Managing People Through Transitions

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Jo cover the aspects of organizational roles and responsibilities, along with how to plan and implement organizational change. In addition, they also explain methods, practices and techniques relating to assessing organizational readiness for, monitoring progress of,  and organizational change.
episodes.title: Managing People Through Transitions Part 2

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Jo discuss how to manage Stakeholders. JO explains the importance of Stakeholder management strategy, changes in stakeholder commitment and even shares tools such as a Stakeholder map to help perform analysis.
episodes.title: Managing People Through Transitions Part 3

episodes.description: In this show, Jo and Cherokee take a look at how to streamline a process through the use of process models. They encourage the use of process models to facilitate efficient and effective processes that are appealing and not perceived as bureaucratic.
episodes.title: ST Processes - Transition Planning and Support

episodes.description: In this show, Jo and Cherokee take a look at how to streamline a process through the use of process models. They encourage the use of process models to facilitate efficient and effective processes that are appealing and not perceived as bureaucratic.
episodes.title: Process Models

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and JO define Change  Management as a way to control the lifecycle of all changes whilst enabling beneficial changes to be made with minimum disruption to IT Services. Jo explains the numerous ways it should add value to a business and not add add layers of complexity or bureaucracy.
episodes.title: ST Processes - Change Management

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Jo continue to discuss Change Management. Jo explains how it adds value to the business, characterizes qualities of poor Change Management, and more. She also shows the differences between normal, standard and emergency changes. Tune in for more!
episodes.title: ST Process - Change Management Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Jo continue to discuss Change Management. Jo identifies inputs such as policies and strategies, RFCs, and change proposals. She them compares those inputs to what an expected output looks like.
episodes.title: ST Processes - Change Management Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Jo explain the purpose of Configuration Management and how it ensures  the assets required to deliver services are properly controlled, that accurate and reliable information about those assets is available when and where required and includes details of how the assets have been configured and the relationships between them.
episodes.title: ST Processes - SACM

episodes.description: In this episode, Jo and Cherokee continue to discuss SACM. Specifically, Jo describes the breakdown of configuration management systems and the including the logical layers of the Configuration Management System (CMS). In addition to internal structure Jo explains the integration of the Definitive Media Library (DMS), and the Configuration Management Data Base(s) (CMDB).
episodes.title: ST Processes - SACM Part 2

episodes.description: In this show, Jo and Cherokee explain how Change Evaluation provides a consistent and standardized means of determining the performance of a service change in the context of likely impacts on business outcomes and on existing services and infrastructure.
episodes.title: ST Processes - Change Evaluation

episodes.description: In this show, Jo and Cherokee explain how to plan and implement a structured validation and test process in addition to explaining the significance to provide an expected quality assurance. Jo also covers how to identify, assess and address issues throughout Service Transition.
episodes.title: ST Processes - Service Validation and Testing

episodes.description: In this show Cherokee and Jo continue talking about service validation and testing. Jo reminds us how how this concept will not be a one size fits all as it greatly depends on what we are testing and how we are testing it. They discuss examples of KPIs to help determine various CSFs. Tune in for all this and more!
episodes.title: ST Processes - Service Validation, Testing Pt. 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.517
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.517 --> 00:00:02.018
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3

[CROSSTALK]
[SOUND]

4
00:00:08.197 --> 00:00:14.935
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:14.935 --> 00:00:16.945
>> I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:16.945 --> 00:00:19.389
This is actually a part two,
a continuation,

7
00:00:19.389 --> 00:00:22.279
where we will look at service
validation and testing.

8
00:00:22.279 --> 00:00:25.180
And back in studios with us today,
we have Mrs. Jo Peacock.

9
00:00:25.180 --> 00:00:26.249
How's it going today, Jo?

10
00:00:26.249 --> 00:00:28.505
>> I'm fine, thank you,
Cherokee, how are you?

11
00:00:28.505 --> 00:00:30.755
>> I'm doing great,
I'm glad that you're back in studios.

12
00:00:30.755 --> 00:00:34.497
Didn't leave us hanging here with a part
two, because we really weren't finished

13
00:00:34.497 --> 00:00:37.128
talking about service validation and
testing, were we?

14
00:00:37.128 --> 00:00:41.257
>> We weren't, but from now on really,
what we're going to be looking at is very,

15
00:00:41.257 --> 00:00:42.750
very, subjective.

16
00:00:42.750 --> 00:00:46.290
Because service validation and
testing really is

17
00:00:46.290 --> 00:00:51.052
completely dependent on what service it
is that you are validating and testing.

18
00:00:51.052 --> 00:00:58.110
And so, once we have a very,
sort of, high level

19
00:00:58.110 --> 00:01:02.890
recommendation for a framework, there is
no generic framework that we can give you.

20
00:01:02.890 --> 00:01:06.060
Like with everything in ITIL,
it’s not a one size fits all the approach.

21
00:01:06.060 --> 00:01:07.644
It can't be a one size fits all approach.

22
00:01:07.644 --> 00:01:10.980
And so we're gonna say to you, well you
need to go away and do some testing.

23
00:01:10.980 --> 00:01:12.216
And you need to plan for

24
00:01:12.216 --> 00:01:17.090
your testing, but this would come as
part of your project management team for

25
00:01:17.090 --> 00:01:21.510
your large implementations because
they will plan for the testing.

26
00:01:21.510 --> 00:01:24.123
I mean, let's take a look at
this first slide here and

27
00:01:24.123 --> 00:01:26.680
you see the process activities.

28
00:01:26.680 --> 00:01:30.955
Look at this, plan and design the test,
verify the test design,

29
00:01:30.955 --> 00:01:35.881
prepare the test environment,
perform the tests, whatever they may be.

30
00:01:35.881 --> 00:01:40.061
And then evaluate what the result of
the tests were, and then clean up,

31
00:01:40.061 --> 00:01:43.220
let's clean up the test environment.

32
00:01:43.220 --> 00:01:47.410
And then this gets fed in, the results
get fed back in to change evaluation,

33
00:01:47.410 --> 00:01:48.370
as you see.

34
00:01:48.370 --> 00:01:53.460
So, what we're saying is, well,
we're going to plan, and then we're gonna

35
00:01:53.460 --> 00:01:57.270
verify, and then we're gonna prepare the
tests and then we're gonna perform them.

36
00:01:57.270 --> 00:01:59.890
And that's exactly what we're going to do.

37
00:01:59.890 --> 00:02:04.840
And we can't really
expand too much more on

38
00:02:04.840 --> 00:02:09.580
these particular activities purely because
they're going to be incredibly subjective

39
00:02:09.580 --> 00:02:13.650
to whatever it is that
you are actually testing.

40
00:02:15.160 --> 00:02:18.420
So let's take a look at what
starts off validation and

41
00:02:18.420 --> 00:02:22.060
testing, well, an RFC,
a request for change.

42
00:02:22.060 --> 00:02:26.950
Which is the request for
a new service, and of course,

43
00:02:26.950 --> 00:02:29.760
that's come through service design.

44
00:02:29.760 --> 00:02:34.160
So this is going to be a project
plan that's going to come to us.

45
00:02:34.160 --> 00:02:37.840
That's going to require us to
perform validation and testing.

46
00:02:37.840 --> 00:02:41.110
And of course,
that project plan is Included in what we

47
00:02:41.110 --> 00:02:43.160
called the service design package.

48
00:02:43.160 --> 00:02:46.250
Now, if you want to see more
about the service design package,

49
00:02:46.250 --> 00:02:49.390
then please take a look at
our service design show.

50
00:02:49.390 --> 00:02:52.150
And there's an episode in there
where we will take a look

51
00:02:52.150 --> 00:02:54.610
at the contents of
the service design package.

52
00:02:54.610 --> 00:02:58.520
And if we look in the design
coordination process,

53
00:02:58.520 --> 00:03:01.719
then you'll find that a lot more
about that service design package.

54
00:03:02.830 --> 00:03:05.800
But it includes things like
the service charter and

55
00:03:05.800 --> 00:03:07.810
also the service level agreements.

56
00:03:07.810 --> 00:03:11.860
So at least the SLRs, the draft service
level agreements, and release and

57
00:03:11.860 --> 00:03:12.980
deployment plans.

58
00:03:12.980 --> 00:03:17.030
Well, release and deployment plans, I'm
hoping, would contain some form of testing

59
00:03:17.030 --> 00:03:20.250
guidance as well,
including test conditions too.

60
00:03:21.630 --> 00:03:23.230
So, what comes out of testing?

61
00:03:23.230 --> 00:03:25.190
Well, the results of testing,

62
00:03:25.190 --> 00:03:28.310
that's what comes out of
service validation and testing.

63
00:03:28.310 --> 00:03:34.330
And it's delivered to change evaluation,
so that they may evaluate that change.

64
00:03:34.330 --> 00:03:39.930
And evaluate whether the change will
deliver what it's supposed to deliver.

65
00:03:39.930 --> 00:03:45.166
And have the tests proved that it's going
to actually facilitate those outcomes,

66
00:03:45.166 --> 00:03:47.271
which is what we want to achieve.

67
00:03:47.271 --> 00:03:49.440
So, what else comes out of there?

68
00:03:49.440 --> 00:03:53.705
Well, updated information for, it mentions
our service knowledge management system,

69
00:03:53.705 --> 00:03:57.755
but I wanna think about
configuration management system too.

70
00:03:57.755 --> 00:04:01.345
Because don't forget, our configuration
management system contains that accurate

71
00:04:01.345 --> 00:04:06.715
and reliable information about all of
our components of our services and

72
00:04:06.715 --> 00:04:09.490
those configuration items.

73
00:04:09.490 --> 00:04:14.756
And so, updates and potential updates to
be for deployment to our configuration

74
00:04:14.756 --> 00:04:19.720
management system, that comes out of
service validation and testing too.

75
00:04:19.720 --> 00:04:22.862
Now, it mentions improvement ideas for
CSI.

76
00:04:22.862 --> 00:04:27.928
Well, as I already referred to in
a previous episode, as we're going through

77
00:04:27.928 --> 00:04:33.070
conducting every single test, not only
are we getting the results of the test,

78
00:04:33.070 --> 00:04:36.755
but we're also working out
what test mechanisms work and

79
00:04:36.755 --> 00:04:40.765
what test mechanisms didn't work quite so
well for us.

80
00:04:40.765 --> 00:04:44.705
So, they are improvement initiatives for
CSI.

81
00:04:44.705 --> 00:04:50.735
So, that next time we perform testing,
well, we've got a streamlined way to test.

82
00:04:50.735 --> 00:04:53.815
We know what works and we know what
doesn't work in our environment.

83
00:04:55.295 --> 00:04:59.205
Another output is
third-party relationships.

84
00:04:59.205 --> 00:05:01.275
That's what's mentioned in there.

85
00:05:03.190 --> 00:05:09.570
I'd like to think that we can perform
testing hand in hand with our supplies.

86
00:05:09.570 --> 00:05:14.136
Quite often, when we had a third-party
supplier that's brought a piece of

87
00:05:14.136 --> 00:05:16.989
software for us,
whether it's off the shelf or

88
00:05:16.989 --> 00:05:22.213
whether it's something that they developed
in bespoke or tailor made fashion for us.

89
00:05:22.213 --> 00:05:26.023
Well, I'd like to think that we had a very
good working relationship with that

90
00:05:26.023 --> 00:05:27.430
supplier.

91
00:05:27.430 --> 00:05:32.150
But I also have to add a caveat into that,
in that, a supplier, no matter who

92
00:05:32.150 --> 00:05:36.190
they are, are only ever going to
give you their best testing results.

93
00:05:36.190 --> 00:05:37.650
And even if you were to ask them for

94
00:05:37.650 --> 00:05:43.350
the worst case scenario, they'll still
give you the best worst case scenario.

95
00:05:43.350 --> 00:05:45.510
So we have to be very,
very careful with that.

96
00:05:45.510 --> 00:05:48.780
Now, I'm not saying that you should take
that with a pinch of salt or anything, but

97
00:05:48.780 --> 00:05:54.040
what I am saying is be very,
very objective about the way that

98
00:05:54.040 --> 00:05:57.375
you view information that
comes from third-parties.

99
00:05:58.480 --> 00:06:03.580
Unless it's information that you have gone
at internally within the organization

100
00:06:03.580 --> 00:06:07.490
then obviously that's going to
be subjective information, and

101
00:06:07.490 --> 00:06:11.030
therefore, you have to
be objective about that.

102
00:06:11.030 --> 00:06:13.260
So, what does service design give us?

103
00:06:13.260 --> 00:06:17.740
Well, service design, well,
that's going to give us testing

104
00:06:17.740 --> 00:06:22.450
criteria because I expect that to
be in the service design package.

105
00:06:22.450 --> 00:06:27.900
And what we feed back to service
design are improvement initiatives for

106
00:06:27.900 --> 00:06:29.700
testing criteria.

107
00:06:29.700 --> 00:06:33.728
So, this is what we tested last time,
and this is what worked really well.

108
00:06:33.728 --> 00:06:37.630
And so therefore,
this is what we should test in the future.

109
00:06:37.630 --> 00:06:40.330
And this is where we missed,
this is what we didn't test and

110
00:06:40.330 --> 00:06:41.660
what we should have tested.

111
00:06:41.660 --> 00:06:45.020
Because we had an incident
after we deployed this service

112
00:06:45.020 --> 00:06:50.670
because we didn't test that particular
functionality or that particular module.

113
00:06:50.670 --> 00:06:53.725
And again, CSI is gonna have
some involvement in that.

114
00:06:53.725 --> 00:06:56.680
Now, into other life cycle phases,

115
00:06:56.680 --> 00:07:00.490
I've gotta put something in here,
in operation, that's not mentioned.

116
00:07:00.490 --> 00:07:03.800
And that is the simple fact that
if you get your testing wrong,

117
00:07:03.800 --> 00:07:07.310
you're gonna get an incident when
it goes to service operation.

118
00:07:07.310 --> 00:07:11.690
When you deploy, if you don't test it
correctly there's going to be a failure.

119
00:07:12.960 --> 00:07:18.220
We can't ignore that, so it’s our
responsibility to get testing right.

120
00:07:18.220 --> 00:07:23.610
And an output to service operation
could be a failure if we get it wrong.

121
00:07:25.020 --> 00:07:26.663
And then service strategy, well,

122
00:07:26.663 --> 00:07:29.520
service strategy tells us how
much money we've got to spend.

123
00:07:29.520 --> 00:07:34.798
And sometimes, I have seen
testing that has been reduced or

124
00:07:34.798 --> 00:07:41.530
that has been, how should we say,
cut short because of lack of money.

125
00:07:41.530 --> 00:07:46.475
Where organizations have said, we don't
have the money to test any further, so

126
00:07:46.475 --> 00:07:48.500
we're just going to release it as it is.

127
00:07:49.960 --> 00:07:54.144
I can't tell you whether that's right or
wrong, because, like I've said before,

128
00:07:54.144 --> 00:07:57.474
ITIL doesn't have the magic solution for
absolutely everything.

129
00:07:57.474 --> 00:08:01.739
We can tell you what best practice is, and
of course, best practice is to fully test.

130
00:08:01.739 --> 00:08:04.970
But then Obviously you
know your environment and

131
00:08:04.970 --> 00:08:08.526
much better than I could
ever know your environment.

132
00:08:08.526 --> 00:08:14.660
So you make those decisions whether
you want to test up to a point or not.

133
00:08:14.660 --> 00:08:17.555
That's completely up to you, obviously.

134
00:08:17.555 --> 00:08:22.845
And what I will say though is that
there is an element of risk management

135
00:08:22.845 --> 00:08:28.061
involved in this, in that if you
decide not to test, there is a risk.

136
00:08:28.061 --> 00:08:31.233
And maybe you feel that,
that decision's been taken away from you,

137
00:08:31.233 --> 00:08:33.376
because of say,
lack of funding, et cetera.

138
00:08:33.376 --> 00:08:36.262
But the simple fact is that
if you decide not to test,

139
00:08:36.262 --> 00:08:38.170
you make the decision not to test.

140
00:08:38.170 --> 00:08:39.848
And if you do, there is a risk.

141
00:08:39.848 --> 00:08:44.534
Now with any risk management technique,
it doesn't matter which one you're using,

142
00:08:44.534 --> 00:08:47.760
you will evaluate whether that
risk is worth taking or not.

143
00:08:47.760 --> 00:08:51.321
And if that risk is worth taking,
then maybe you stop testing.

144
00:08:51.321 --> 00:08:56.455
If the risk is not worth taking, then
maybe you carry on with the testing and

145
00:08:56.455 --> 00:08:59.265
try and save some money somewhere else.

146
00:08:59.265 --> 00:09:03.801
>> Jo, you bring up a really good point
because, I mean, in a perfect world,

147
00:09:03.801 --> 00:09:06.473
we would want to follow
these rules to the T.

148
00:09:06.473 --> 00:09:08.875
But sometimes when it comes down to it,
like you said,

149
00:09:08.875 --> 00:09:11.030
sometimes that decision
is taken away from you.

150
00:09:11.030 --> 00:09:14.778
If it comes down to the application
that you've been developing for

151
00:09:14.778 --> 00:09:18.722
the past six months and your direct
competitor has caught wind of it, or

152
00:09:18.722 --> 00:09:21.748
they're about to release
a very similar version, and

153
00:09:21.748 --> 00:09:25.232
it really comes down to which
company's gonna make it or fail,

154
00:09:25.232 --> 00:09:28.359
then that's where these
decisions can come into play.

155
00:09:28.359 --> 00:09:33.757
But perfect world or best case scenario
is to follow the guidelines, of course.

156
00:09:33.757 --> 00:09:36.530
>> Well,
we see this every day in our real life.

157
00:09:36.530 --> 00:09:40.851
And I'd just mentioned money and,
but timing is another issue.

158
00:09:40.851 --> 00:09:45.091
And timing is something that
will force reduced testing and

159
00:09:45.091 --> 00:09:47.479
reduced stringency of testing.

160
00:09:47.479 --> 00:09:48.720
But we see this every day.

161
00:09:48.720 --> 00:09:50.990
Let's take a look at our cell phones,
for instance.

162
00:09:50.990 --> 00:09:52.733
We've all got a cell phone.

163
00:09:52.733 --> 00:09:57.091
And we know for a fact that there are cell
phones that are released or maybe

164
00:09:57.091 --> 00:10:02.640
operating systems of cell phones that are
released right at the very last minute.

165
00:10:02.640 --> 00:10:06.604
And you really, really think to
yourself that this particular model or

166
00:10:06.604 --> 00:10:11.163
this particular operating system would
have benefited from maybe another week in

167
00:10:11.163 --> 00:10:12.038
development.

168
00:10:12.038 --> 00:10:16.024
But because a particular provider
needed to get to market first,

169
00:10:16.024 --> 00:10:18.090
they released early.

170
00:10:18.090 --> 00:10:20.342
And we see this all the time.

171
00:10:20.342 --> 00:10:21.980
But again it's about risk management.

172
00:10:21.980 --> 00:10:26.902
And there has to be an element of risk
management that evaluates whether it's

173
00:10:26.902 --> 00:10:30.130
worth releasing at that point in time or
not.

174
00:10:30.130 --> 00:10:36.030
And sometimes organizations will
determine that it's better for

175
00:10:36.030 --> 00:10:40.880
them to release early with
potential errors than it

176
00:10:40.880 --> 00:10:45.000
is to release later than the competition
but at least have it error free,

177
00:10:45.000 --> 00:10:47.570
because you don't know what
the competition is going to be like.

178
00:10:48.600 --> 00:10:56.160
So what does then our service validation
and testing process have to achieve?

179
00:10:56.160 --> 00:11:03.450
Well, we've gotta be able to measure a
service's ability to perform as expected.

180
00:11:04.640 --> 00:11:11.499
And if we can't measure that, then even
though we can test absolutely everything,

181
00:11:11.499 --> 00:11:16.327
if we can't measure whether it works or
not, then we have no

182
00:11:16.327 --> 00:11:22.337
demonstration as to whether a service
is going to perform when required.

183
00:11:22.337 --> 00:11:25.444
So in terms of critical success factors,

184
00:11:25.444 --> 00:11:31.136
we've got to ensure that we take into
perspective all of our stakeholders.

185
00:11:31.136 --> 00:11:34.695
That we take into account
everything that they want to see.

186
00:11:34.695 --> 00:11:39.015
Remember the discussion that we had
at the beginning of our last episode,

187
00:11:39.015 --> 00:11:42.788
where we looked at the difference
between a customer and a user.

188
00:11:42.788 --> 00:11:46.280
They have two very,
very completely different perspectives.

189
00:11:46.280 --> 00:11:49.198
But then another stakeholder,
or our support team and

190
00:11:49.198 --> 00:11:53.090
our service desk,
they have a different perspective too.

191
00:11:53.090 --> 00:11:57.890
So we have to ensure that we take into
consideration all of their perspectives.

192
00:11:57.890 --> 00:12:03.160
And in terms of KPIs, look at the KPIs
that we have listed with that CSF.

193
00:12:03.160 --> 00:12:08.540
So increasing in services where we
understand all roles and responsibilities.

194
00:12:08.540 --> 00:12:11.490
Where roles are documented and

195
00:12:11.490 --> 00:12:15.909
where customers, stakeholders,
users, support people are happy.

196
00:12:16.955 --> 00:12:23.284
Encouraging a risk management culture,
that's an interesting CSF even.

197
00:12:23.284 --> 00:12:25.240
[LAUGH] Isn't it?

198
00:12:25.240 --> 00:12:28.020
I mean, encouraging risk management?

199
00:12:28.020 --> 00:12:32.028
Risk management, by the way,
doesn't mean that we take risks.

200
00:12:32.028 --> 00:12:34.840
It means that we manage risks.

201
00:12:34.840 --> 00:12:38.320
It means that we evaluate risks and
we make a decision.

202
00:12:39.340 --> 00:12:40.449
It's completely different
from taking risks.

203
00:12:40.449 --> 00:12:44.370
>> And here I thought I was
just living on the edge, Jo.

204
00:12:44.370 --> 00:12:45.976
>> [LAUGH]
>> No, no, no,

205
00:12:45.976 --> 00:12:49.270
you've evaluated your risks and then
you've decided what you're going to do.

206
00:12:49.270 --> 00:12:50.773
This is not about living on the edge.

207
00:12:50.773 --> 00:12:52.336
>> [LAUGH]
>> But

208
00:12:52.336 --> 00:12:56.367
look at the KPIs as far as
risk management is concerned.

209
00:12:56.367 --> 00:13:00.708
We want people that feel
able to identify risks.

210
00:13:00.708 --> 00:13:03.630
And we want to be able
to document those risks.

211
00:13:03.630 --> 00:13:06.521
And we actually wanna see more
risks in the risk register.

212
00:13:06.521 --> 00:13:11.297
That's a bit of frightening, all three
of those are actually quite frightening

213
00:13:11.297 --> 00:13:15.058
KPIs because a lot of people feel
too scared to identify risks.

214
00:13:15.058 --> 00:13:18.860
They don't wanna be the one that sort
of raises their hand tentatively and

215
00:13:18.860 --> 00:13:23.330
says, I see a potential problem here.

216
00:13:23.330 --> 00:13:27.670
And a lot of times, depending on
the culture of the organization,

217
00:13:27.670 --> 00:13:32.399
that has a huge part to do with this,
that culture could actually prevent

218
00:13:32.399 --> 00:13:37.232
people from raising their hands and
saying, I foresee a potential risk.

219
00:13:37.232 --> 00:13:38.353
And you know what?

220
00:13:38.353 --> 00:13:43.236
That last KPI where I say that we probably
need to increase the number of risks

221
00:13:43.236 --> 00:13:45.110
on the risk register.

222
00:13:45.110 --> 00:13:47.869
Again another scary KPI.

223
00:13:47.869 --> 00:13:50.564
Because most people will look at that and
say, no,

224
00:13:50.564 --> 00:13:53.140
we wanna have a reduction
in the number of risks.

225
00:13:53.140 --> 00:13:54.381
But we don't.

226
00:13:54.381 --> 00:13:58.500
Cuz if I don't see any risks on the risk
register, I will turn around and

227
00:13:58.500 --> 00:14:02.553
tell you very, very simply that you
simply haven't identified any or

228
00:14:02.553 --> 00:14:05.750
that you're trying to
avoid identifying risks.

229
00:14:05.750 --> 00:14:10.111
And that's definitely
what we don't want to do.

230
00:14:10.111 --> 00:14:11.868
So what about all the CSS that we've got?

231
00:14:11.868 --> 00:14:15.860
Reusable test models,
absolutely fantastic.

232
00:14:15.860 --> 00:14:19.540
We definitely need to be testing
in a consistent way, but

233
00:14:19.540 --> 00:14:23.280
we do that in the understanding that
all of our services are different.

234
00:14:24.530 --> 00:14:26.660
So we have test models.

235
00:14:26.660 --> 00:14:29.780
But that doesn't mean that we
see everything exactly the same,

236
00:14:29.780 --> 00:14:32.910
it just means that we have
a standard approach to testing.

237
00:14:33.990 --> 00:14:37.924
Go back to part one of service
validation and testing,

238
00:14:37.924 --> 00:14:43.156
where we actually looked at planning
our tests and having test scripts.

239
00:14:43.156 --> 00:14:45.449
These are part of our
reusable test models.

240
00:14:45.449 --> 00:14:48.575
And these should be stored in a database.

241
00:14:48.575 --> 00:14:52.560
These should be stored within our
knowledge management repository,

242
00:14:52.560 --> 00:14:54.010
most definitely.

243
00:14:54.010 --> 00:14:58.418
So I wanna see an increase in the number
of times that tests have been reused.

244
00:14:58.418 --> 00:15:02.670
And what about that balance between
costing of testing and effectiveness?

245
00:15:02.670 --> 00:15:04.948
Well, we just talked about earlier on,

246
00:15:04.948 --> 00:15:09.236
about quite often we'll get some form
of directive that says, that's it,

247
00:15:09.236 --> 00:15:14.300
I don't wanna do any more testing, because
we've spent enough money in testing.

248
00:15:14.300 --> 00:15:19.571
Or even to the point where we want
to release early because we've got

249
00:15:19.571 --> 00:15:24.668
time constraints on us dictated
by our competitors, et cetera.

250
00:15:24.668 --> 00:15:27.515
We acknowledge that this
sort of thing happens.

251
00:15:27.515 --> 00:15:31.648
But we want to try and
ensure that if we are as efficient and

252
00:15:31.648 --> 00:15:36.042
as effective as we possibly can
be within our environment and

253
00:15:36.042 --> 00:15:41.385
within our testing processes,
then actually we never get to that point,

254
00:15:41.385 --> 00:15:45.121
because we're as efficient
as we possibly can be.

255
00:15:45.121 --> 00:15:49.507
So take a look at those KPI's there,
including reduced cost in fixing errors,

256
00:15:49.507 --> 00:15:53.369
because we're detecting them earlier and
reduced business impact,

257
00:15:53.369 --> 00:15:56.062
because we're not actually
delaying testing.

258
00:15:56.062 --> 00:15:57.238
We're getting on with testing.

259
00:15:57.238 --> 00:16:00.908
Again, think about efficiency.

260
00:16:00.908 --> 00:16:05.295
And understanding risks, you know that CSF
goes back to that previous CSF where I

261
00:16:05.295 --> 00:16:07.180
talked about identifying risks.

262
00:16:08.300 --> 00:16:13.490
I want everyone to ensure that they
feel confident in identifying risk and

263
00:16:13.490 --> 00:16:18.050
that they don't feel any pressure
to not identify or to hide risks.

264
00:16:19.820 --> 00:16:22.740
Ultimately, what we have got to overcome

265
00:16:22.740 --> 00:16:27.910
in order to be able to be effective
in Service Validation and Testing,

266
00:16:27.910 --> 00:16:32.580
as we have got to overcome our
challenges that we have listed here.

267
00:16:32.580 --> 00:16:35.750
In another words, we have got
to have a test environment, and

268
00:16:35.750 --> 00:16:38.840
we've got to have people
with the right skills.

269
00:16:38.840 --> 00:16:40.330
And look at that next one there.

270
00:16:40.330 --> 00:16:44.240
You know, Cherokee, that's exactly
what you mentioned about time scales,

271
00:16:44.240 --> 00:16:49.070
being tightened because we want to
get out to market very quickly.

272
00:16:51.080 --> 00:16:56.700
If we don't set clear expectations for
testing, this is when we run

273
00:16:56.700 --> 00:17:01.070
into those types of challenges to do with
time scales and to do with budget as well.

274
00:17:01.070 --> 00:17:05.620
Because if we don't tell everybody
exactly what's expected within

275
00:17:05.620 --> 00:17:09.610
the testing environment and
within the testing of any service,

276
00:17:09.610 --> 00:17:14.660
people will assume that you can just
test just like that, really quickly.

277
00:17:14.660 --> 00:17:16.560
Well, if only that were the case.

278
00:17:16.560 --> 00:17:19.270
We're talking about large
scale implementation here, so

279
00:17:19.270 --> 00:17:24.820
therefore testing is not gonna be
something that you can do overnight.

280
00:17:24.820 --> 00:17:28.970
Look at that risk there about the lack
of appreciation that risk comes from

281
00:17:28.970 --> 00:17:30.506
poorly targeted testing.

282
00:17:30.506 --> 00:17:35.870
We've got to plan our testing and
it's gonna be comprehensive as well.

283
00:17:35.870 --> 00:17:38.840
We have to ensure that we
test absolutely everything.

284
00:17:40.480 --> 00:17:43.700
So who do we have in terms of roles and

285
00:17:43.700 --> 00:17:47.830
responsibilities then within
service validation and testing?

286
00:17:47.830 --> 00:17:51.140
Well, think back to ITL foundation,

287
00:17:51.140 --> 00:17:55.060
recap on our roles and responsibilities
and we have a process owner.

288
00:17:55.060 --> 00:18:00.070
Process owner who is accountable for
an overall testing strategy.

289
00:18:00.070 --> 00:18:06.330
And then we'll have a Service and
Validation Testing Process Manager

290
00:18:06.330 --> 00:18:09.560
reports to the Service Transition Manager.

291
00:18:11.260 --> 00:18:12.150
Interestingly enough,

292
00:18:12.150 --> 00:18:16.340
what it does say there is that those
two roles should not be combined.

293
00:18:17.440 --> 00:18:21.770
So testing is not combined with
release and deployment management.

294
00:18:21.770 --> 00:18:25.720
Why do you think we shouldn't
combine testing with release and

295
00:18:25.720 --> 00:18:26.790
deployment management?

296
00:18:26.790 --> 00:18:31.640
>> Well, this kind of goes to the whole
concept of I really want my network

297
00:18:31.640 --> 00:18:36.960
engineers performing my penetration tests
because there may be some underlying bias.

298
00:18:36.960 --> 00:18:41.500
And you're really only getting
that initial perspective

299
00:18:41.500 --> 00:18:45.780
that an application or software or
design was created with.

300
00:18:45.780 --> 00:18:48.920
So you're not getting an additional
perspective, or a different

301
00:18:48.920 --> 00:18:53.580
set of eyes because they might not see
the issues that someone else could see, or

302
00:18:53.580 --> 00:18:56.800
they might not be hiding
the fact that hey,

303
00:18:56.800 --> 00:18:59.475
I'm perfect, there could be
nothing wrong with the system.

304
00:18:59.475 --> 00:19:02.210
>> [LAUGH] That's exactly it.

305
00:19:02.210 --> 00:19:04.450
I'm so glad you mentioned that.

306
00:19:04.450 --> 00:19:07.338
I don't know about whether they wander
around saying hey look, I'm perfect.

307
00:19:07.338 --> 00:19:11.514
Although mind you,
I met some network engineers.

308
00:19:11.514 --> 00:19:16.270
[LAUGH] But what I am saying is that
there's a conflict of interest there.

309
00:19:16.270 --> 00:19:16.900
>> Sure.

310
00:19:16.900 --> 00:19:20.850
>> Testing, we want to test it and
we want to break it.

311
00:19:20.850 --> 00:19:22.326
That's what to do in testing.

312
00:19:22.326 --> 00:19:24.290
But we're listening to
deployment management.

313
00:19:24.290 --> 00:19:27.290
We've got perhaps our developers
maybe performing release and

314
00:19:27.290 --> 00:19:28.430
deployment management.

315
00:19:28.430 --> 00:19:30.630
But irrespective of whether
it's our developers or

316
00:19:30.630 --> 00:19:34.920
whether we've got a separate team, the
simple fact is that they have a deadline.

317
00:19:36.540 --> 00:19:39.380
And it could be our project
management team that are performing

318
00:19:39.380 --> 00:19:41.180
the release the deployment.

319
00:19:41.180 --> 00:19:42.230
They've got a deadline.

320
00:19:42.230 --> 00:19:44.476
They have got a date that
they want to meet and

321
00:19:44.476 --> 00:19:46.363
they have got to get the service out.

322
00:19:46.363 --> 00:19:49.080
And the problem is that
the testing manager,

323
00:19:49.080 --> 00:19:52.950
the people doing the testing on
that team are trying to break it.

324
00:19:54.270 --> 00:19:57.930
Well, of course, our release guys will
say no, no there's nothing wrong there,

325
00:19:57.930 --> 00:19:59.410
I just want to get it out.

326
00:19:59.410 --> 00:20:03.060
And the testing guys are saying
hang on a minute, hang on, hang on,

327
00:20:03.060 --> 00:20:04.410
I haven't tested this.

328
00:20:04.410 --> 00:20:08.855
I want to get this tested cuz I swear I
saw an error in the script somewhere.

329
00:20:08.855 --> 00:20:11.790
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, you've got two conflicting

330
00:20:11.790 --> 00:20:17.106
objectives, which is why we say that
those two roles shouldn't be combined.

331
00:20:17.106 --> 00:20:20.623
Cuz the service validation and
testing manager, well,

332
00:20:20.623 --> 00:20:23.040
they need to perform all of the tests and

333
00:20:23.040 --> 00:20:28.530
they need to be satisfied that everything
has been tested before release.

334
00:20:28.530 --> 00:20:30.393
Or as the release and deployment manager,

335
00:20:30.393 --> 00:20:33.149
well, their objective is to get
it out as quickly as possible.

336
00:20:33.149 --> 00:20:36.430
Now you'd like to think that there was
some sort of synergy between the two.

337
00:20:36.430 --> 00:20:40.190
And I am sure most organizations
we can be growing up about it and

338
00:20:40.190 --> 00:20:44.499
we can be adult about this and
we working together as a team.

339
00:20:45.630 --> 00:20:48.879
But nevertheless, we want to keep
the two activities separate.

340
00:20:48.879 --> 00:20:52.800
And I'm not saying that people
don't work together as a team, but

341
00:20:52.800 --> 00:20:56.794
because that conflict of interest and
the conflict of objectives,

342
00:20:56.794 --> 00:21:00.660
it doesn't make sense to give those
two roles to the same person.

343
00:21:01.760 --> 00:21:05.080
And then, we've got people that
actually perform the testing.

344
00:21:05.080 --> 00:21:06.770
And we call these our practitioners,

345
00:21:06.770 --> 00:21:11.760
because as we go back to our foundation
material, our process practitioners

346
00:21:11.760 --> 00:21:16.280
are the people that actually perform
individual activities with the processors.

347
00:21:16.280 --> 00:21:19.260
So look at what they're doing,
they're conducting the tests,

348
00:21:19.260 --> 00:21:23.210
they're recording the findings
of their testing as well.

349
00:21:23.210 --> 00:21:26.040
And they're the people that
are contributing towards the evaluation

350
00:21:26.040 --> 00:21:30.960
reports and the testing reports too
to go back to change evaluation.

351
00:21:30.960 --> 00:21:34.070
So I'd expect these people to
be technical people as well.

352
00:21:35.910 --> 00:21:37.540
So that's pretty much it.

353
00:21:37.540 --> 00:21:41.134
That kinda wraps it up for
service validation and testing.

354
00:21:41.134 --> 00:21:44.040
Now, you do have exercises.

355
00:21:44.040 --> 00:21:48.440
And I know that I didn't highlight any
exercises at the end of our last episode,

356
00:21:48.440 --> 00:21:51.750
but in our last episode I asked you
to look at our service v model.

00:21:51.750 --> 00:21:54.310
Well now,
in your downloadable material, you will

00:21:54.310 --> 00:21:56.961

00:21:56.961 --> 00:22:00.350
>> Yeah, right [LAUGH] yeah,
those sorts of exercise.

360
00:22:00.350 --> 00:22:02.545
>> Jo's like, Cherokee just hold on.

00:22:02.545 --> 00:22:04.467
[LAUGH]
>> I know,

362
00:22:04.467 --> 00:22:09.340
I'm not too sure what it is today
I can't help her, I'm sorry.

363
00:22:09.340 --> 00:22:12.230
But you do have some exercises to do,
okay?

364
00:22:12.230 --> 00:22:13.622
If you wanna do jumping jacks,

365
00:22:13.622 --> 00:22:17.270
while you're performing the exercises
then go knock yourself out, all right?

366
00:22:17.270 --> 00:22:18.515
Don't let me stop you.

367
00:22:18.515 --> 00:22:22.610
[LAUGH] Please, please,
please go ahead and

368
00:22:22.610 --> 00:22:27.570
look at the activities that you've been

369
00:22:27.570 --> 00:22:32.785
And as always, I would like you to know

370
00:22:32.785 --> 00:22:34.428
If you do have any queries and

00:22:34.428 --> 00:22:38.059
if you do have any questions at
all about service validation and

372
00:22:38.059 --> 00:22:42.890
testing, then please feel free to ask,

373
00:22:42.890 --> 00:22:45.920
>> All right, thanks Jo, and

But we are out of time for

episodes.title: ST Processes - Release and Deployment Mgmt

episodes.description: In this show, Jo and Cherokee continue to discuss Release and Deployment Management . Jo explains the differences between a release process trigger versus a deployment trigger. They also examine how those triggers interface with the four phases of Release and Deployment Management. Inputs, outputs and more are covered as well!
episodes.title: ST Processes - Release and Deployment Mgmt Pt.2

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Jo foster ideas on how to share perspectives, ideas, experience and information. They also stress the need to  ensure these  ideas are available to enable informed decisions; and to reduce the need to rediscover knowledge. Jo encourages the idea idea of Service Knowledge Management System (SKMS)  as a logical way to interrogate data and the relationships between the configuration items thus providing knowledge and facts to help execute informed decisions.

25

26

27

[LAUGH] It's not scary-

28

29

30

31

And it's not really even about having
all of our information in one place.

32
00:01:17.690 --> 00:01:23.770
It's about having information, so that we
can get access to that information and

33
00:01:23.770 --> 00:01:25.990
to allow us to make informed decisions.

34
00:01:25.990 --> 00:01:30.070
If we don't have anything recorded, and we
don't have anything written down anywhere,

35
00:01:30.070 --> 00:01:33.130
then all of our decisions are going
to be based on I think so.

36
00:01:34.330 --> 00:01:35.790
I think that's not good enough.

37
00:01:35.790 --> 00:01:38.830
We have to make decisions
based on evidence.

38
00:01:38.830 --> 00:01:40.620
And so,
that's what Knowledge Management does.

39
00:01:40.620 --> 00:01:45.270
It ensures that we have not just
only got the evidence in place,

40
00:01:45.270 --> 00:01:49.065
but that we have access to that evidence,
as well.

41
00:01:49.065 --> 00:01:51.348
Let's take a look at the purpose
of Knowledge Management.

42
00:01:51.348 --> 00:01:55.363
And you'll see that it's there to share
perspectives, and ideas, and experience,

43
00:01:55.363 --> 00:01:56.700
and information.

44
00:01:56.700 --> 00:02:01.080
To ensure that they're available to
the right person at the right time to

45
00:02:01.080 --> 00:02:03.330
enable informed decision making.

46
00:02:04.900 --> 00:02:06.260
Whenever I see the word wisdom,

47
00:02:06.260 --> 00:02:08.190
I automatically think of
Knowledge Management.

48
00:02:08.190 --> 00:02:12.750
And whenever I see the word decision
making, I think of Knowledge Management.

49
00:02:12.750 --> 00:02:18.700
It's really about enabling us, as in the
service provider, to be more efficient.

50
00:02:18.700 --> 00:02:23.050
And to be able to make decisions
that are actually effective

51
00:02:23.050 --> 00:02:26.300
by having that right
information available to us.

52
00:02:26.300 --> 00:02:29.830
So it means that we have the right
information available to us.

53
00:02:29.830 --> 00:02:34.701
That our customers and our users also have
the right information available to them to

54
00:02:34.701 --> 00:02:36.766
enable their decision making too.

55
00:02:36.766 --> 00:02:40.460
In other words enabling
their use of our services.

56
00:02:40.460 --> 00:02:41.450
Don't forget,

57
00:02:41.450 --> 00:02:45.170
when I keep saying this at the start
of every single episode that a service

58
00:02:45.170 --> 00:02:50.540
is a means of delivering value which is
perceived by facilitating an outcome.

59
00:02:50.540 --> 00:02:53.310
And sometime just having FAQ's available

60
00:02:53.310 --> 00:02:56.610
to our users helps them
to facilitate an outcome.

61
00:02:56.610 --> 00:03:03.880
Because if they can log on to an FAQ area
to gain information about maybe how to add

62
00:03:03.880 --> 00:03:09.360
two cells together in Excel, for instance,
then that delivers value to them.

63
00:03:09.360 --> 00:03:12.780
So this is about enabling
informed decision making.

64
00:03:12.780 --> 00:03:14.965
It's about delivering value but

65
00:03:14.965 --> 00:03:19.113
by having the right information
available at our fingertips.

66
00:03:19.113 --> 00:03:23.985
So we have what we call a service
knowledge management system which

67
00:03:23.985 --> 00:03:26.508
gives us access to all of our data.

68
00:03:26.508 --> 00:03:30.232
Now I do not want you to
think of a service knowledge

69
00:03:30.232 --> 00:03:33.880
management system as
being a physical concept.

70
00:03:35.160 --> 00:03:41.500
It's not, a service knowledge management
system is actually a logical concept.

71
00:03:41.500 --> 00:03:46.630
And it's a logical concept that looks
at the relationships between all of

72
00:03:46.630 --> 00:03:48.440
our data sources.

73
00:03:48.440 --> 00:03:50.940
So think about all of our databases.

74
00:03:50.940 --> 00:03:53.200
Think about our configuration
management database and

75
00:03:53.200 --> 00:03:55.390
our configuration management system.

76
00:03:55.390 --> 00:03:59.171
And when we looked at service asset and
configuration management,

77
00:03:59.171 --> 00:04:02.810
I said that we need to have
a federated database system.

78
00:04:02.810 --> 00:04:06.280
In other words, we need to ensure that
if we update information in one place,

79
00:04:06.280 --> 00:04:10.489
then we update information in all of
the other databases automatically.

80
00:04:11.860 --> 00:04:15.090
And then I went on a little bit further
because then I started talking about

81
00:04:15.090 --> 00:04:20.010
that interaction between configuration
management and incident management.

82
00:04:20.010 --> 00:04:22.570
And I mentioned that you know when
you call the service desk and

83
00:04:22.570 --> 00:04:27.020
they verify your user ID with you,
then you verify the information.

84
00:04:27.020 --> 00:04:29.060
And if a service desk analyst says,

85
00:04:29.060 --> 00:04:31.400
well I've got you down as
being on the third floor.

86
00:04:31.400 --> 00:04:34.160
And you say,
no I'm not I'm on the first floor now,

87
00:04:34.160 --> 00:04:38.420
then they update the information that
they have in the call logging tool.

88
00:04:38.420 --> 00:04:41.750
And that automatically updates
the information in the configuration

89
00:04:41.750 --> 00:04:42.930
management system.

90
00:04:42.930 --> 00:04:46.880
So now I've just inferred just by saying
though that there’s a relationship

91
00:04:46.880 --> 00:04:51.690
that exists between incident management
and configuration management.

92
00:04:51.690 --> 00:04:53.930
And that’s right, there is.

93
00:04:53.930 --> 00:04:56.110
So now we're gonna have
those same relationships and

94
00:04:56.110 --> 00:04:59.500
we're gonna put that into place with
all of our other databases too.

95
00:04:59.500 --> 00:05:02.400
Such as our availability
management information system or

96
00:05:02.400 --> 00:05:08.320
our capacity management information system
or our customer agreement database.

97
00:05:08.320 --> 00:05:13.708
Or our service portfolio with our pipeline
and our catalog and our retired services.

98
00:05:13.708 --> 00:05:18.180
And our change management system and
our request fulfillment system and

99
00:05:18.180 --> 00:05:19.868
our known error database.

100
00:05:19.868 --> 00:05:22.700
And all of these other databases,
our supplier and

101
00:05:22.700 --> 00:05:24.860
contract management information system.

102
00:05:24.860 --> 00:05:29.360
We've got all of the databases that
we have within IT are listed here

103
00:05:29.360 --> 00:05:32.250
in our material that you can download.

104
00:05:32.250 --> 00:05:35.630
But just think of the other
databases that we have within IT.

105
00:05:35.630 --> 00:05:39.350
We have got so many different databases.

106
00:05:39.350 --> 00:05:44.480
A database is a storage system for data.

107
00:05:46.470 --> 00:05:51.010
If we update data in one particular place,

108
00:05:51.010 --> 00:05:54.710
we shouldn't be updating
it somewhere else.

109
00:05:55.870 --> 00:06:02.830
If we do that, if we have to duplicate our
effort, then not only is it not efficient,

110
00:06:02.830 --> 00:06:07.649
but also it leaves me questioning
which data is accurate?

111
00:06:07.649 --> 00:06:10.039
Where is our accuracy?

112
00:06:10.039 --> 00:06:12.981
So service knowledge management system,

113
00:06:12.981 --> 00:06:18.900
as we've referred to in that slide,
that SKMS, is not a physical concept.

114
00:06:18.900 --> 00:06:22.666
It's a logical concept that refers to
the relationships between all of our

115
00:06:22.666 --> 00:06:24.140
databases.

116
00:06:24.140 --> 00:06:28.310
And so it allows me to
interrogate all of our data

117
00:06:28.310 --> 00:06:31.660
contained in our databases in one go.

118
00:06:32.940 --> 00:06:34.920
That's what knowledge management is about.

119
00:06:34.920 --> 00:06:39.220
Now I've referred to data a lot, but

120
00:06:39.220 --> 00:06:44.340
these are data sources where all of our
individual databases are data sources.

121
00:06:44.340 --> 00:06:47.860
And on their own,
they have very limited use.

122
00:06:47.860 --> 00:06:52.460
If I just think about incident management
as a core login system on its own,

123
00:06:52.460 --> 00:06:54.640
it has very limited use.

124
00:06:54.640 --> 00:06:59.040
But I add in relationships
to other services or

125
00:06:59.040 --> 00:07:03.560
to other tools and adding in relationships
to my configuration management system.

126
00:07:03.560 --> 00:07:07.480
I add in relationships to
my network discovery tools.

127
00:07:07.480 --> 00:07:12.910
I add in relationships to a tool that
will allow remote desktop support for

128
00:07:12.910 --> 00:07:18.024
instance, then all of a sudden, I have
information available at my fingertips.

129
00:07:19.110 --> 00:07:23.150
I mentioned those words previously
when I started talking about

130
00:07:23.150 --> 00:07:25.870
configuration management,
when we looked at service asset and

131
00:07:25.870 --> 00:07:28.330
configuration management, or SACM.

132
00:07:28.330 --> 00:07:31.680
And I said, watch out for these words
cuz they're gonna be very important.

133
00:07:31.680 --> 00:07:35.970
And now I'm using them again, and here
they are in the slide in front of you, but

134
00:07:35.970 --> 00:07:37.720
there are other words in there.

135
00:07:37.720 --> 00:07:39.640
The word knowledge and the word wisdom.

136
00:07:41.250 --> 00:07:46.310
You see, we have what we call
the data to wisdom tree or DIKW,

137
00:07:46.310 --> 00:07:51.783
as we like to call it data,
information, knowledge and wisdom.

138
00:07:51.783 --> 00:07:53.584
And it simply works like this,

139
00:07:53.584 --> 00:07:57.131
on their own individual data
sources have very limited use.

140
00:07:57.131 --> 00:08:00.112
So what I do is I add in relationships.

141
00:08:00.112 --> 00:08:02.225
And that gives me information.

142
00:08:02.225 --> 00:08:08.564
I analyze those relationships and that
gives me knowledge, tells me something.

143
00:08:08.564 --> 00:08:12.904
And I use that knowledge, normally this
knowledge is presented by way of a nice

144
00:08:12.904 --> 00:08:15.158
pretty picture or a graph or something.

145
00:08:15.158 --> 00:08:21.190
I use that knowledge to make an informed
decision, thereby giving me wisdom.

146
00:08:22.190 --> 00:08:24.863
Now, let's think about this
in a little bit more depth.

147
00:08:24.863 --> 00:08:27.190
You see, we can automate a lot of this.

148
00:08:27.190 --> 00:08:28.900
We can automate data collection.

149
00:08:28.900 --> 00:08:31.140
We can use discovery tools, etc.

150
00:08:31.140 --> 00:08:33.890
And we can even automate
our use of relationships.

151
00:08:33.890 --> 00:08:38.616
Remember that automation of the service
desk analyst updated a field in

152
00:08:38.616 --> 00:08:43.658
the core login system and that
automatically updates, via relationship,

153
00:08:43.658 --> 00:08:48.280
the updates the data in our
configuration management system.

154
00:08:48.280 --> 00:08:52.582
So we can automate information and
thereby we can automate knowledge,

155
00:08:52.582 --> 00:08:56.610
that production of those reports but
you can't automate wisdom.

156
00:08:56.610 --> 00:08:57.740
[LAUGH] You still don't.

157
00:08:57.740 --> 00:08:59.630
Just because we produce
a nice pretty picture,

158
00:08:59.630 --> 00:09:02.569
doesn't mean that somebody's gonna
make the right decision from them.

159
00:09:02.569 --> 00:09:03.611
>> And use it in the right way, right.

160
00:09:03.611 --> 00:09:05.300
>> Right, exactly.

161
00:09:05.300 --> 00:09:06.820
But by that same token,

162
00:09:06.820 --> 00:09:11.100
I've talked about making a decision
from a nice pretty picture from a graph.

163
00:09:11.100 --> 00:09:15.859
We will tell you that it's never
going to be efficient to have 10,000

164
00:09:15.859 --> 00:09:19.719
graphs produced when no one's
making a decision from them.

165
00:09:19.719 --> 00:09:23.584
And so we will tell you that, quite
simply, if you can't make a decision from

166
00:09:23.584 --> 00:09:26.738
that report, or nobody is making
decisions from that report,

167
00:09:26.738 --> 00:09:29.700
then really you shouldn't
be producing that report.

168
00:09:29.700 --> 00:09:32.060
>> That's a great point,
Jo, because I mean,

169
00:09:32.060 --> 00:09:36.310
even in different types of software that
I've worked with and you get these reports

170
00:09:36.310 --> 00:09:41.150
generated, sometimes you can get
almost like a book of information.

171
00:09:41.150 --> 00:09:45.390
And especially if it's really tedious or
just technical information and

172
00:09:45.390 --> 00:09:47.780
you're sitting down at the meeting and
you're passing this information, or

173
00:09:47.780 --> 00:09:49.650
however your method of delivery there.

174
00:09:49.650 --> 00:09:53.340
But it's like you don't even wanna look
at it, so why would anyone else want to?

175
00:09:53.340 --> 00:09:57.830
So understanding who will be looking and
using this information is really huge.

176
00:09:57.830 --> 00:10:02.415
>> People get something by advertising and
by media marketing sometimes.

177
00:10:02.415 --> 00:10:06.739
And I'll tell people all the time when
they are going out to evaluate say,

178
00:10:06.739 --> 00:10:10.576
any particular tool and no matter
what that tool is just because it

179
00:10:10.576 --> 00:10:15.280
says on the box that it produces 500
reports means absolutely nothing.

180
00:10:15.280 --> 00:10:18.643
When none of those reports
are relevant for you.

181
00:10:18.643 --> 00:10:20.239
>> [LAUGH]
>> You gotta be able

182
00:10:20.239 --> 00:10:20.754
to use,
>> Exactly.

183
00:10:20.754 --> 00:10:21.669
>> Those reports.

184
00:10:21.669 --> 00:10:25.275
And so,
I don't care if it produces 500 reports.

185
00:10:25.275 --> 00:10:29.232
If I don't need those reports,
if they're not telling me anything,

186
00:10:29.232 --> 00:10:33.995
they're not allowing me to improve and
they're not allowing me to make decisions,

187
00:10:33.995 --> 00:10:36.086
then those reports are irrelevant.

188
00:10:36.086 --> 00:10:41.123
And as you said, years ago and nowadays
most things are done electronically,

189
00:10:41.123 --> 00:10:44.403
but years ago,
I used to sit at my desk sometimes and

190
00:10:44.403 --> 00:10:48.625
I'd get a book this thick of reports
delivered to me every month.

191
00:10:48.625 --> 00:10:52.145
And I would look at them and say,
I don't need half of these reports.

192
00:10:52.145 --> 00:10:54.680
I don't need to look at these reports.

193
00:10:54.680 --> 00:10:58.710
If I want them and I want that
information, I know that it's there.

194
00:10:58.710 --> 00:11:00.380
But I don't need these reports and

195
00:11:00.380 --> 00:11:03.010
this is exactly what knowledge
management will tell you.

196
00:11:03.010 --> 00:11:08.432
Is that, if you can't make a decision from
it or you're now going to make a decision

197
00:11:08.432 --> 00:11:13.171
from it, then it is not efficient for
you to be producing those reports.

198
00:11:13.171 --> 00:11:15.906
It's just reporting for
the sake of reporting.

199
00:11:15.906 --> 00:11:18.580
>> [LAUGH] Well that sounds like fun.

200
00:11:18.580 --> 00:11:20.820
Let's just go and
generate some more reports, Jo.

201
00:11:20.820 --> 00:11:23.342
[LAUGH]
>> Well exactly, I could wallpaper my

202
00:11:23.342 --> 00:11:27.310
whole entire houses for the amount
of irrelevant reports I've seen.

203
00:11:27.310 --> 00:11:28.250
Trust me.

204
00:11:28.250 --> 00:11:29.273
I mean, they look pretty.

205
00:11:29.273 --> 00:11:30.821
They have nice, pretty colors on them.

206
00:11:30.821 --> 00:11:32.277
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

207
00:11:32.277 --> 00:11:35.264
>> So, knowledge really is all about

208
00:11:35.264 --> 00:11:39.899
having the available information
at the right time to

209
00:11:39.899 --> 00:11:43.350
enable those informed decisions.

210
00:11:43.350 --> 00:11:48.710
But we have to, as we've already said,
we have to be able to make a decision from

211
00:11:48.710 --> 00:11:51.940
any knowledge that we have
presented in front of us.

212
00:11:51.940 --> 00:11:57.680
And knowledge includes things like
when solve utilization of the service.

213
00:11:57.680 --> 00:12:01.320
It includes things like risk awareness
as well and risk management.

214
00:12:01.320 --> 00:12:04.250
Knowledge is really
the analysis of the information

215
00:12:04.250 --> 00:12:07.510
that we have at our fingertips,
that's all knowledge is.

216
00:12:07.510 --> 00:12:11.750
And that's to say, normally this is
produced by way of a nice pretty picture.

217
00:12:11.750 --> 00:12:17.320
So when I talk about not producing reports
just for the sake of producing reports,

218
00:12:17.320 --> 00:12:21.530
we should always have policies for
what reports are produced,

219
00:12:21.530 --> 00:12:26.580
why we need each report, and
when are we going to review each report?

220
00:12:26.580 --> 00:12:30.840
And this is not just about reports, this
is about all of our documentation as well.

221
00:12:30.840 --> 00:12:32.650
All of our policies, all of our plans and

222
00:12:32.650 --> 00:12:35.720
all of our documentation should
be reviewed on a regular basis.

223
00:12:37.430 --> 00:12:41.893
I see data sources and
I see document repository systems,

224
00:12:41.893 --> 00:12:44.085
EDRMSs we like to call them.

225
00:12:44.085 --> 00:12:47.391
SharePoint is one example, where we
just keep building and building and

226
00:12:47.391 --> 00:12:48.539
building and building.

227
00:12:49.640 --> 00:12:54.965
And while we'll tell you you should never
